text: Jeremiah was called to be a prophet during the reign of which king of Judah?
verseText: the word of the LORD came to him in the days of Josiah the son of Amon, king of Judah, in the thirteenth year of his reign.

text: What was Jeremiah's initial objection when God called him?
options: He was afraid of the king
verseText: Then I said, “Ah, Lord GOD! Behold, I do not know how to speak, for I am only a youth.”

text: What two evils did God accuse His people of committing in Jeremiah 2:13?
options: Forsaking Him (the fountain of living waters) and hewing out broken cisterns
Ignoring the poor and oppressing the weak
Breaking the Sabbath and disrespecting priests
verseText: for my people have committed two evils: they have forsaken me, the fountain of living waters, and hewed out cisterns for themselves, broken cisterns that can hold no water.

text: Jeremiah is often called the '__________ Prophet' because of his sorrowful message and experiences.
verseText: (Refers to the overall tone and Jeremiah's laments, like 'Oh that my head were waters, and my eyes a fountain of tears, that I might weep day and night for the slain of the daughter of my people!')

text: What object lesson did God use in Jeremiah 18 involving a potter?
options: A broken pot cannot be mended
God's sovereign power to reshape Israel like clay
verseText: And the vessel he was making of clay was spoiled in the potter's hand, and he reworked it into another vessel, as it seemed good to the potter to do... O house of Israel, can I not do with you as this potter has done? declares the LORD. Behold, like the clay in the potter's hand, so are you in my hand, O house of Israel.

text: Who was Jeremiah's scribe who wrote down his prophecies on a scroll?
verseText: Then Jeremiah called Baruch the son of Neriah, and Baruch wrote on a scroll at the dictation of Jeremiah all the words of the LORD that he had spoken to him.

text: What did King Jehoiakim do with the scroll containing Jeremiah's prophecies?
options: He cut it up and burned it
verseText: As Jehudi read three or four columns, the king would cut them off with a scribe's knife and throw them into the fire in the brazier, until the entire scroll was consumed in the fire that was in the brazier.

text: In Jeremiah 29, what did Jeremiah advise the exiles in Babylon to do?
options: Build houses, plant gardens, seek the welfare of the city
Try to escape back to Jerusalem
verseText: Build houses and live in them; plant gardens and eat their produce... seek the welfare of the city where I have sent you into exile, and pray to the LORD on its behalf, for in its welfare you will find your welfare.

text: Jeremiah 31 speaks of a 'New Covenant'. How will it differ from the old one?
options: It will be written on stone tablets
It will be only for the priests
God will write His law on their hearts
verseText: For this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, declares the LORD: I will put my law within them, and I will write it on their hearts. And I will be their God, and they shall be my people.

text: Where was Jeremiah thrown when he was accused of deserting to the Babylonians?
verseText: So they took Jeremiah and cast him into the cistern of Malchiah, the king's son, which was in the court of the guard, letting Jeremiah down by ropes. And there was no water in the cistern, but only mud, and Jeremiah sank in the mud.

text: What nation did God frequently use Jeremiah to prophesy against, warning Judah of impending judgment from them?
Jeremiah used the imagery of a marred linen loincloth hidden near the Euphrates River to symbolize what?
options: The spoiled pride of Judah and Jerusalem
The strength of the Babylonian army

text: What did God forbid Jeremiah from doing as a sign of the coming sorrow and desolation in Judah?
Which false prophet clashed with Jeremiah, breaking the symbolic yoke Jeremiah wore and falsely prophesying a quick return from exile?
During the siege of Jerusalem, what controversial action did Jeremiah perform as a sign of faith in God's promise of future restoration?
options: He wrote a poem of hope
He bought a field in his hometown Anathoth

text: Who rescued Jeremiah from the muddy cistern where he had been left to die?
After the fall of Jerusalem, Gedaliah was appointed governor by the Babylonians but was later assassinated. Where did the remaining Judeans, against Jeremiah's warning, decide to flee?
Jeremiah prophesied that the exile in Babylon would last for how many years?
What symbolic action involving large stones did Jeremiah perform in Tahpanhes, Egypt, to signify Babylon's future dominance even there?
options: Hiding them in the brick pavement at Pharaoh's palace entrance

text: Besides Judah, Jeremiah also delivered prophecies concerning which other nations?
options: Only the nations immediately bordering Judah
Egypt, Philistia, Moab, Ammon, Edom, Damascus, Kedar, Hazor, Elam, and Babylon

text: What title or metaphor does God use for King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, indicating his role as an instrument of divine judgment?
In his lament, Jeremiah compares his suffering and the destruction of Jerusalem to what?
options: A city whose walls are breached (as detailed in Lamentations, traditionally attributed to him)

text: What specific sin related to worship does Jeremiah repeatedly condemn among the people of Judah, particularly associated with the Valley of Hinnom?
King Zedekiah, the last king of Judah, often sought Jeremiah's counsel but ultimately failed to do what?
options: Heed Jeremiah's advice to surrender to Babylon
Appoint Jeremiah as his chief advisor

text: What does Jeremiah promise will happen to the descendants of David and the Levites in the context of the New Covenant and restoration?
options: They will be replaced by foreign rulers
Their lines will continue and multiply

text: Who was Pashhur, the priest, known for doing to Jeremiah?
options: Having him beaten and put in stocks

text: Jeremiah warned the people against trusting in the physical presence of what building, thinking it guaranteed their safety?
options: The Temple of the LORD in Jerusalem

text: What did God compare Israel to in Jeremiah's time, suggesting they had become wild and untamed?
The Rechabites were commended by God through Jeremiah for what specific act of obedience?
options: Obeying their ancestor's command not to drink wine or build houses

text: What future righteous figure did Jeremiah prophesy would descend from David, known as 'The LORD is our Righteousness'?
When the first scroll of Jeremiah's prophecies was destroyed, what did God command Jeremiah to do?
options: Rewrite the scroll, adding more words
Challenge the king to a debate

text: Jeremiah lamented that he had become an object of what to the people?
What natural disaster did Jeremiah use as an analogy for God's judgment and the resulting devastation?
God tells Jeremiah He knew him and set him apart before what event?
options: Before the reign of King Josiah
Before he was born / formed in the womb

text: What did Jeremiah accuse the prophets and priests of Jerusalem of doing?
options: Healing the wound of God's people lightly, saying 'Peace, peace,' when there is no peace
Encouraging strict obedience to the Law
Spending too much time in prayer
Ignoring the needs of the king

text: In the vision of the two baskets of figs shown to Jeremiah, what did the good figs represent?
options: The wicked people remaining in Judah
The exiles taken to Babylon whom God would restore

text: What did the bad figs, which were too rotten to eat, represent in Jeremiah's vision?
options: King Zedekiah and the officials remaining in Jerusalem, destined for disaster

text: Jeremiah wore a yoke on his neck as a symbol. What was it meant to represent?
options: Submission to the king of Babylon

text: Where was Jeremiah from?
God promised to gather the remnant of His flock from all the countries where they were scattered and bring them back to do what?
options: Be fruitful and multiply in their own pasture
Build a new temple in Babylon

text: What emotion did Jeremiah express when contemplating the deception of false prophets?
Jeremiah accused the people of Judah of turning God's house into what?
What does God promise regarding the knowledge of Him under the New Covenant?
options: All will know Him, from the least to the greatest

text: What characteristic of God is emphasized in the New Covenant promise regarding Israel's past sins?
options: His forgiveness and remembering sins no more

text: Who sought to kill Jeremiah because of his prophecies of doom against Jerusalem and the Temple?
options: The priests, the prophets, and officials

text: Which official defended Jeremiah, reminding the assembly of the prophet Micah who prophesied similarly in Hezekiah's time without being killed?
Jeremiah prophesied that which city, once a center of worship, would become a desolate ruin like Shiloh?
What does God instruct Jeremiah to tell the nations using the metaphor of a cup of wrath?
options: That they must drink from it, signifying judgment
That they should share it peacefully

text: How did Jeremiah describe the human heart?
options: Deceitful above all things and desperately sick

text: What did Jeremiah observe about the stork, turtledove, swallow, and crane that contrasted with Israel's behavior?
options: They migrated predictably, knowing their seasons, unlike Israel knowing God's laws

text: Jeremiah lamented being deceived or overpowered by God, feeling compelled to speak God's word even when it brought him pain. What imagery did he use for the word within him?
options: A fire shut up in his bones

text: What punishment did God decree for the false prophet Shemaiah who sent letters from Babylon undermining Jeremiah?
options: He and his descendants would not see the good God would do for His people

text: In a prophecy of restoration, God promises to bring Israel and Judah back from captivity and cause them to possess what?
options: The land promised to their fathers

text: What sound does Jeremiah prophesy will cease in the towns of Judah and streets of Jerusalem due to the coming judgment?
options: The sounds of joy and gladness, bride and bridegroom

text: Despite the grim prophecies, Jeremiah includes messages of hope, such as the restoration of fortunes and the rebuilding of what city?
Who was Seraiah, Baruch's brother, tasked with doing when he went to Babylon with King Zedekiah's delegation?
options: Reading Jeremiah's prophecies against Babylon and then sinking the scroll in the Euphrates

text: What happened to King Zedekiah's sons when he was captured by the Babylonians?
options: They were taken as hostages to Babylon
They were killed before his eyes

text: After being captured, what punishment did King Zedekiah himself suffer?
options: He was released and sent to Egypt
His eyes were put out, and he was taken in chains to Babylon
He was made a servant in Nebuchadnezzar's court

text: Who gave the orders to the Babylonian captain of the guard, Nebuzaradan, to treat Jeremiah well after Jerusalem's fall?
Given the choice after Jerusalem's fall, where did Jeremiah initially choose to stay?
options: Remain in Judah with Gedaliah and the remnant

text: What specific idolatrous practice did the Judean refugees in Egypt, particularly the women, vow to continue despite Jeremiah's warnings?
options: Making offerings to the Queen of Heaven

text: Jeremiah prophesied that the Judean remnant who fled to Egypt seeking safety would ultimately face what?
options: Sword, famine, and plague, with few survivors

text: What sign did God give through Jeremiah to prove His word against the refugees in Egypt would stand?
options: Pharaoh Hophra being handed over to his enemies

text: What personal promise did God give to Baruch, Jeremiah's scribe, amidst the widespread destruction?
options: He would be spared death and his life given as a prize
He would lead the exiles back

text: The final chapter of Jeremiah (Chapter 52) largely serves as what?
options: A historical appendix detailing the fall of Jerusalem and the exile, similar to 2 Kings 24-25

text: What positive event concerning the exiled King Jehoiachin is recorded at the very end of the book of Jeremiah?
options: His release from prison and elevation in the Babylonian court

text: Jeremiah compared searching for a righteous person in Jerusalem to searching with what?
What did God say He would make His words in Jeremiah's mouth?
The people of Anathoth, Jeremiah's hometown, threatened him with what if he continued prophesying?
What agricultural metaphor did Jeremiah use to describe the superficial repentance of Israel?
What did Jeremiah lament finding when he looked for grapes on the vine or figs on the fig tree, symbolizing Israel's lack of righteousness?
God tells Jeremiah not to pray for the well-being of the people of Judah because their wickedness was too great. This highlights the severity of what?
What does Jeremiah ask God regarding the prosperity of the wicked?
options: How he can become prosperous too
Why the way of the wicked prospers
If their prosperity is a sign of God's favor

text: Jeremiah prophesied that the Davidic king who would reign justly was also called by what name?
What did the officials do to Jeremiah after hearing Baruch read the scroll, before taking it to King Jehoiakim?
options: Advised Jeremiah and Baruch to hide

text: What specific judgment did Jeremiah pronounce against King Jehoiakim for burning the scroll?
options: He would win a great victory
He would have a long and prosperous reign
He would have no descendant sitting on David's throne and his body would be cast out
He would repent and be forgiven

text: Jeremiah's letter to the exiles countered the advice of false prophets who were promising what?
options: An immediate or very quick return to Jerusalem

text: The promise of the New Covenant includes the assurance that God will be their God and they shall be His what?
King Zedekiah secretly consulted Jeremiah during the final siege. What was Jeremiah's consistent message to him?
options: Surrender to the Babylonians to save the city and his own life

text: What reason did the officials give for wanting to execute Jeremiah during the siege?
options: He was discouraging the soldiers and people by advocating surrender
He stole from the temple treasury

text: What does the name 'Jeremiah' possibly mean?
Jeremiah's ministry spanned the reigns of which kings of Judah?
What image does God use to describe His relationship with Israel, which they broke?
Jeremiah condemned the people for putting misplaced trust in 'lying words' by chanting what phrase repeatedly?
options: 'The Temple of the LORD, the Temple of the LORD, the Temple of the LORD!'

text: What did God promise to give the people after His own heart, who would lead them with knowledge and understanding, replacing the unfaithful leaders?
The book of Jeremiah contains several sections often referred to as Jeremiah's 'Confessions' or 'Laments'. What do these passages primarily express?
options: His personal anguish, struggles with God, and persecution
His detailed plans for the temple
